DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Lower as Cold Snap Eases
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed modestly lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as temperatures in U.S. growing areas rose, slowing feed-grain demand and easing transportation problems. Soybeans for near-term delivery slipped below $5.70 a bushel for the first time since early November. The soybean market had risen sharply in recent weeks as temperatures fell in the Great Plains and Midwest, reflecting the increased demand for soybean meal as a high-energy livestock feed. Further selling of soybean futures was linked to reports of light rain in southern Brazil over the weekend and forecasts for more moisture in the region, one of the world's major soybean-producing areas. It is early summer in Brazil. Dry weather during the planting season had stirred drought fears, but those concerns have faded as growing conditions have improved in recent weeks. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.10 a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $1.53\ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3} cents lower with January at $5.68{ a bushel.
